Expectation1: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation1: A house has structural wood damage from termites, and the carpenter needs to provide an urgent repair plan
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story:
I was bent over the splintered beams in Mrs. Lee’s living room, my hands tracing the deep grooves left by termites. She watched me anxiously, waiting for my urgent repair plan—her house was at risk of collapse if I didn’t act fast. As a carpenter, I knew my responsibility: assess the damage, secure the structure, and keep her safe. My mind raced through options, calculating materials and time, when suddenly the city’s flood alarms blared outside. Through the window, I saw water creeping up the street, neighbors shouting as they scrambled to move cars and sandbags.

As a citizen, I was expected to help—join the effort, check on the elderly, follow emergency protocols. But as a carpenter, I couldn’t leave Mrs. Lee’s house in this state; the weakened beams could give way at any moment. My phone buzzed with city alerts, urging evacuation and community action. My heart pounded, torn between the duty to my craft and the call to stand with my neighbors. I stood frozen, the weight of both roles pressing down, unsure which demand I could bear to ignore.
